title: 112_s187
content: The "Biofuels Market Expansion Act of 2011" requires manufacturers to ensure a certain percentage of dual-fueled automobiles and light duty trucks for sale in the United States. The "Biofuels Market Expansion Act of 2011" mandates that manufacturers produce dual-fueled vehicles, with 50% for model years 2014 and 2015, and 90% for model year 2016 onwards. There is an exception for vehicles running solely on electricity. Additionally, a new section is added to the code, and regulations must be established within a year of the Act's enactment. The "Blender Pump Grant Program" defines a blender pump as a fuel dispenser capable of dispensing various gasoline and ethanol blends, including E-85 fuel and ethanol fuel blends. The "Blender Pump Grant Program" defines a blender pump as a fuel dispenser capable of dispensing various gasoline and ethanol blends, including E-85 fuel and ethanol fuel blends. The program allows for grants to eligible facilities to cover a portion of the costs associated with the implementation of blender pumps. The grants are administered by the Secretary of Energy and are available to major fuel distributors who own or directly market the output of a refinery. The Secretary will provide grants to eligible facilities for installing blender pump fuel infrastructure, including pumps and storage tanks for ethanol fuel blends. Major fuel distributors are not eligible for these grants. The Federal share of project costs under this subsection can be up to 50%. If a facility receiving a grant does not offer ethanol fuel blends for sale for at least 2 years within a 4-year period, they must repay the grant amount. Authorization of appropriations for the installation of blender pumps by major fuel distributors at owned and branded stations includes $50 million for 2012, $100 million for 2013, $200 million for 2014, $300 million for 2015, and $350 million for 2016. The authorization of appropriations for the installation of blender pumps by major fuel distributors at owned and branded stations includes definitions for E-85 fuel, ethanol fuel blend, and major fuel distributor. The term 'fuel distributor' refers to a person who owns a refinery or directly markets its output, excluding those who market through less than 50 retail fueling stations. The term 'Secretary' refers to the Secretary of Energy, who will promulgate regulations for major fuel distributors. The Secretary of Agriculture will promulgate regulations requiring major fuel distributors to install blender pumps dispensing E-85 fuel and ethanol blends at majority-owned and branded stations for at least 5 years. The applicable percentage will be specified by the major fuel distributor. The Secretary of Agriculture will require major fuel distributors to install blender pumps dispensing E-85 fuel and ethanol blends at majority-owned and branded stations for 5 years, with the applicable percentage determined by the distributor. The Secretary of Agriculture mandates major fuel distributors to install E-85 fuel and ethanol blends at stations, with increasing percentages from 10% in 2014 to 50% in 2020 and beyond. The Secretary of Agriculture requires major fuel distributors to install blender pumps dispensing E-85 fuel and ethanol blends at a specified minimum percentage of their stations in each state where they operate. The Secretary mandates major fuel distributors to ensure financial responsibility for installing blender pumps dispensing E-85 fuel and ethanol blends in each state where they operate. Production credits are earned by major fuel distributors who exceed the required percentage of blender pumps installation at their stations. These credits can be applied to any of the 3 consecutive calendar years following the year they are earned. Trading of credits is also allowed. Major fuel distributors can earn production credits by exceeding the required blender pump installation percentage. These credits can be used in the 3 consecutive calendar years following their earning. Trading of credits is permitted, but purchased credits cannot be used to fulfill the geographic distribution requirement. "Loan guarantees available for renewable fuel pipeline projects." Loan guarantees are available for renewable fuel pipeline projects. Definitions for renewable fuel and renewable fuel pipeline are provided in the Energy Policy Act of 2005, with renewable fuel including all types of ethanol and biodiesel. The amount of guarantee for a project related to renewable fuel pipelines is specified in the Act. Loan guarantees are available for renewable fuel pipeline projects under the Energy Policy Act of 2005. The Act specifies that the guarantee amount for such projects is 80% of the facility's estimated project cost at the time of issuance. Additionally, the Act includes provisions for the eligibility of renewable fuel pipelines and the rapid deployment of such projects. The Energy Policy Act of 2005 allows for loan guarantees for renewable fuel pipeline projects, with the guarantee amount set at 80% of the project cost. The Act also includes provisions for the eligibility and rapid deployment of such projects. The Secretary of Energy is required to promulgate necessary regulations within 90 days of the Act's enactment.
